Before you can use this trigger action, you need to register your system as a Twitter client. This trigger action uses OAuth to authenticate with Twitter, and therefore requires you to obtain API access first. You only need to do this once for all Update Twitter Status trigger actions within the system.

To register your system, go to Twitter's OAuth Clients page, and click on "Create a new application". Enter any system root URL as the Callback URL (it will be ignored - Matrix will provide it with a correct callback URL).

When you complete the registration, it will provide you with a consumer key and a consumer secret string, which you need to enter below.

Apps are created Read Only by default. Make sure Read and Write is selected in the setting tab after registration.

Once you have entered the consumer key and consumer secret string into the boxes above and commit, a "Sign in with Twitter" link will appear. Click this and follow the prompts to complete the authentication process. Remember to sign in with the Twitter account you want to tweet to.

You will temporarily leave the Matrix backend during this process - permission is granted through the Twitter site. Your Matrix session will remain active (subject to session length rules), and you will be redirected back to this trigger once authentication is complete.

You can use any global keyword, or asset keyword (which uses the triggering asset). In addition, you can use the keyword %asset_short_url% to refer to the shortest URL that can be used to point to this asset - whether this is the main URL or a remap. It may be useful to add an Add Remap action before this one, to ensure a short URL (based on asset ID) is created which can then be used by this action.

Due to the variable length of keyword replacements, the box above will not limit you to 140 characters. You may determine what occurs when the length of the tweet (with all keywords replaced) is longer than 140 characters. If you choose Abbreviate where possible, the parts of text which are not links will be abbreviated to reduce the size to 140 characters, where possible - if not reasonably possible, the trigger will fail. Or you can choose to simply Fail the trigger.
